title: Can AI Be Religious
section: What Does it Mean to Be Religious
text:
What Does it Mean to Be Religious

Religion is belief, practice, community, and ritual. Itâ€™s a relationship to something greater than oneself- whether thatâ€™s a God, the universe, or a sacred tradition. And itâ€™s person. People cry, doubt, repent, and feel transformed through their faith.

AI, on the other hand, doesnâ€™t believe in anything (I think). Large language models like GPT-4 donâ€™t understand the words that they generate. Theyâ€™re complex pattern-matching systems that predict what text should come next based on massive amounts of data. When they compose a prayer or sermon, theyâ€™re not speaking to God. Theyâ€™re mirroring what theyâ€™ve seen humans say.

But what if that mirroring is enough to move someone?

title: Can AI Be Religious
text:
The Illusion of Understanding

Thereâ€™s a famous philosophical idea called the Chinese Room Argument. Imagine someone locked in a room who doesnâ€™t speak Chinese, but who follows a rulebook to respond to Chinese messages in a way that looks fluent to outsiders. From the outside, it seems like this locked up person understands Chinese, but inside, they donâ€™t really understand anything.

Thatâ€™s sort of how I describe LLMs to operate. They can perform faith, but they donâ€™t practice it. When an AI writes a Psalm-like message, thereâ€™s no feeling. Itâ€™s just generating what is statistically learned to be â€œappropriate.â€

title: Can AI Be Religious
section: Why Do People Still Use AI Spiritually?
text:
Why Do People Still Use AI Spiritually?

People are still using AI for religious purposes. Some ask AI to write personalized prayers, others use it to generate sermons or interpret scripture.

In a way, AI is filling a gap. In a world where many people feel disconnected from traditional institutions, some are looking for spiritual expression in new, digital forms.

title: Can AI Be Religious
text:
Respect, Risk, and Responsibility

There are real risks in simulating religion through machines. What if the AI generates heretical or offensive comments? What happens when it misrepresents sacred teachings, or blends traditions in ways that confuse or offend practitioners?

Thereâ€™s also a question of authenticity. Is a computer-generated prayer meaningful if itâ€™s not created with intention, emotion, or faith? Can something artificial still offer comfort, or does that comfort rely on some kind of illusion.

Finally, thereâ€™s the danger of misplaced trust. If a chatbox sounds wise or spiritual, people may start treating it like an authority. That could undermind actual religious leaders or traditions, or even steer people towards misinformation cloaked in sacred language.

title: Can AI Be Religious
text:
Letâ€™s Test It Out

  
Hereâ€™s just a little snippet of my conversation with AI and religion.

title: Can AI Be Religious
text:
Soâ€¦ Can AI Be Religious

No.Â It does a good job of given real examples of verses, given my prompt of being an anxious senior. But no. AI cannot believe, worship, or seek transcendence. It can only simulate the surface of religion from the words, the form, and the tone.

But that doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s irrelevant. These simulations can still affect us. They can comfort, inspire, confuse, or provoke us. And in that way, maybe they tell us more about ourselves than about machines.

Because when we ask an AI to pray, the real mystery isnâ€™t what the AI believes - itâ€™s what we are looking for.

title: Guestimation and Making Graphs in R!
text:
Guestimation and Making Graphs in R

I also want to learn how to code more in R, and I really like graphs
Iâ€™m going to ask ChatGPT if they can give me code to make graphs.
These questions will be guestimations on what ChatGPT thinks of certain trend lines.


Letâ€™s cook.

1. Years Lived vs Amount of Friends

Jenn asks: Can you create R code for a graph to show your guestimation on years lived vs amount of friends. 
ChatGPT:
 
When I asked why there was this trend, ChatGPT responded with 
The trend I used in the R code is based on general social patterns observed in human friendships over a lifetime. Hereâ€™s why I shaped it that way: 

Friendships Peak in Young Adulthood (20s-30s) People tend to have the most friends in their teens and 20s, especially in school, university, or early careers. Social environments like college, sports, clubs, and workplaces provide many opportunities for new friendships. Thereâ€™s generally more free time for social activities before major life commitments (e.g., demanding careers, marriage, parenting).
Gradual Decline in Middle Age (30s-50s) In the 30s and 40s, people often prioritize careers, families, and personal responsibilities, leading to less time for socializing. Some friendships naturally fade due to geographical moves, lifestyle changes, or shifting priorities. However, a smaller core group of close friends often remains.
Further Decline in Older Age (60s-80s) Retirement, health issues, and the loss of peers contribute to fewer active friendships. Many elderly people rely more on family, close lifelong friends, or community groups rather than maintaining large social circles. Some older adults reconnect with old friends or develop new friendships in retirement communities, but the overall trend is downward.  Why This Trend Makes Sense? 


Social networks are largest in early adulthood when we have high social mobility and opportunity. 
Life responsibilities impact time and effort spent on friendships as we grow older. 
Aging naturally reduces social engagement, with some maintaining strong bonds but a smaller total number of friends.  Of course, this is a generalizationâ€”individual experiences vary widely! Some people maintain or even expand their social circles in later years. Would you like me to adjust the model to include different factors, such as personality types or social media influence?

And honestly, I think their prediction and trend line is correct. Let us move onâ€¦


2. Age vs Breast Cancer Rates

Jenn asks: and can you write code for age vs breast cancer rates 
ChatGPT: 
 

When I ask why they think it exhibits this trend:

Why This Trend? 
Young women (20-30s): Very low breast cancer rates. Middle age (40-50s): Rates begin to rise due to hormonal and genetic factors. 
Older age (60-80s): Highest incidence rates, as risk accumulates over time. 
This is a simplified model based on general trends seen in epidemiology. Would you like a more specific model with real-world data, or adjustments to include factors like genetic risk?


Overall Conclusions

Iâ€™ve always considered ChatGPT a reliable tool when it comes to helping me understand code in different languages,especially in R. Typically, I use it to assist with analyzing existing datasets, helping me troubleshoot or improve my workflow. However, today I was genuinely impressed by how I only needed to ask a few conceptual questions, and it was able to generate solid estimations and code that made sense. Not only did the graphs it produced align well with the trends I was curious about, but the R code ran smoothly and gave me exactly the visualizations I needed. 
Thatâ€™s what struck me the mostâ€”this wasnâ€™t just assistance with tweaking existing code or interpreting output. ChatGPT created data, understood the implications of trend lines, and executed flawless visualizations with minimal input. Itâ€™s a bit unsettling, to be honest. I understand now why my cousin, a data scientist at GitHub, feels uneasy about AIâ€™s rapid growth, especially when it comes to automating core parts of his job. What does this mean for the future of data science? ChatGPT isnâ€™t just a helpful homework assistant;itâ€™s beginning to replicate, and in some cases streamline, the work that skilled professionals do. The efficiency and accuracy it offers could have real implications for the job market in data-related fields.

title: Spotify DJ Sucks
text:
Analysis of Jennâ€™s Music


Iâ€™ve been having a really hard time with exploring new music.   I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s because I donâ€™t have time to scroll through new playlists, or if I just LOVE listening to the same songs over and over again. I think itâ€™s a combination of both.  
Spotifyâ€™s AI DJ is supposed to help with this. Itâ€™s a personalized music experience that curates playlists and provides commentary. Itâ€™s available to Spotify Premium users in the US and Canada, and now in over 50 different regions.  


Ugh, I donâ€™t know about you but my Spotify DJ SUCKS. It keeps playing the same songs over and over again. I really donâ€™t blame it- I do listen to the same 5 songs on repeat. But sometimes it plays really generic songsâ€¦ and Iâ€™M SICK AND TIRED!  
I remember I took CIS110 in the past, and for one of our homeworks we had to do a music analysis assignment. From what I can remember, the professor provided us with a CSV file of music. There was a lot of different analytics we could explore: duration of song, artist who wrote it, tempo, genre, etc etc.  
I canâ€™t really remember what I did or what I analyzedâ€¦ but Iâ€™m wondering if I could download a few CSV files of my different playlists to see what AI can analyze based off my data.  
My ultimate goal is to see if it does better than Spotify AI DJ when it comes to helping me explore new music, while understanding what type of music Iâ€™d like to listen to based on my playlists.  



Arts N Crafts Playlist


I donâ€™t know if you can tell, but this is a playlist thatâ€™s more folk and country music. Donâ€™t judge me, I know many people hate country. I did too, until I went camping in Maine with friends who put me onto Luke Combs. Anyways. Yea. This is just a mix of music that sort of all give me the same vibes.   But vibes is very subjective. Some of the songs on here arenâ€™t even country or folk- I just put it in their based on my best judgement.   But letâ€™s see what sort of analytics we can pull from this. To start off, Iâ€™m going to download a CSV file of this to pull all the data.  
I asked gpt if it could do some simple analysis first: 

prompt: please help me do R code to make data analysis for this csv of my music from a playlist. can you make a bubble graph


It created a bubble chart with 

X axis: Tempo (beats per minute)
Y axis: Valence (musical positivity)
Bubble Size: Popularity (Spotifyâ€™s popularity score)


 And hereâ€™s the code for it 
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(readr)

# Load the data
df <- read_csv("~/Desktop/arts_n_crafts.csv")

# Create a combined label for top songs
df <- df %>%
  mutate(Label = paste(`Track Name`, "-", `Artist Name(s)`))

# Plot: Bubble chart
ggplot(df, aes(x = Tempo, y = Valence, size = Popularity)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, color = "skyblue") +
  geom_text(data = df %>% top_n(10, Popularity),
            aes(label = Label), size = 3, vjust = 1.2, hjust = 0.5) +
  scale_size(range = c(3, 15)) +
  labs(title = "Bubble Chart of Playlist Songs",
       x = "Tempo (BPM)",
       y = "Valence (Positivity)",
       size = "Popularity") +
  theme_minimal()

I also found the Top 10 Most Popular Songs in the playlist.   
Now that we have this, I want to look at other ways I could find out how to create a prediction model on what new music I would be most drawn to.   So I asked gpt: 

what would be the best way to predict what other new songs I would like based on the music I have in this playlist


What GPT 4o recommended was to 

Audio Feature-Based Similarity


# Average feature profile of your playlist
feature_cols <- c("Valence", "Energy", "Danceability", "Tempo", "Acousticness")
profile <- df %>%
  select(all_of(feature_cols)) %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), mean, na.rm = TRUE))

# Then you can compare new songs using distance from this profile


Clustering Songs I like Using clustering (like K-means) to group my songs into vibes or moods. Then recommend new songs that fall into those clusters

# K-means example
kmeans_result <- kmeans(df[, feature_cols], centers = 3)
df$Cluster <- as.factor(kmeans_result$cluster)


Collaborative Filtering (Spotify Style)  This needs listening data from many users and not only me. It recommends that I use Spotifyâ€™s Recommendations API where I can send my favorite songs or artists and gives me

library(spotifyr)

# Set up authentication (youâ€™ll need a Spotify developer account)
access_token <- get_spotify_access_token()

# Get recommendations based on seed tracks
recommended <- get_recommendations(seed_tracks = c("0GNVXNz7Jkicfk2mp5OyG5"),
                                   limit = 10)


Mood or Genre Tagging  Group my songs by mood (based on valence and energy) or genre (if available), then explore similar ones in that space
Machine Learning (if Iâ€™m ambitious)  If I have song ratings or like/dislike flags, I can train a classification model (like logistic regression or random forest) and the model can predict whether Iâ€™d like a new song based on its feature.



Conclusion: Reimagining Spotify DJ

While I didnâ€™t end up building a better version of Spotify DJ, the process of analyzing my own music taste was surprisingly insightful on its own. It helped me better understand my listening patterns and how much my preferences shift depending on the moment. Iâ€™m especially curious about how GPT-4o might approach recommending new music based on my historyâ€”possibly in a more dynamic or personalized way than Spotifyâ€™s existing DJ. 
From what I can tell, Spotify DJ likely uses a mix of audio featureâ€“based similarity and collaborative filtering. That makes sense for matching my tastes with popular trends and similar users, but Iâ€™m more intrigued by how a machine learning approachâ€”like k-means clusteringâ€”could offer an entirely different way to group my preferences and suggest songs. For instance, Iâ€™m not convinced that mood or genre tagging alone would work well for me, since I might want classical music after an upbeat playlist. My listening doesnâ€™t always follow a predictable emotional or genre path. 
This makes me think that a model trained on listening context or deeper audio features could unlock something more fluid and personalized. Itâ€™s definitely a project I want to revisit when I have more time. Thereâ€™s real potential in going beyond the DJâ€™s prebuilt logic and experimenting with unsupervised learning to build a truly adaptive music recommendation tool.

title: Playing Around With LangChain
text:
What is the term large language model

Large Language Models:  - Large describes the size of these models based on the training data and parameters. - Language model describes the computer algorithm trained to receive written text and to create an output. - Large language models are trained on vast amounts of text and have learned from the patterns in large data sets.
Fun Fact : Most models are better at English than they are in other languages because of the prevalence of English in training models.


How Does LangChain Come Into Play

On October 22, 2022, Harrison Chase was the first the publish the first commit on GitHub for the LangChain open source library.  LangChain was created after discovering that LLM applications needed to use LLMs together with â€œother sources of computation or knowledgeâ€.  It creates simple abstractions for each major prompting technique.


Getting Set Up With LangChain
Iâ€™ll be referencing Oâ€™Reilly â€œChapter 1.LLM Fundementals With LangChainâ€ if you want to follow along! Weâ€™re going to learn how to work with LangChainâ€™s building blocks to understand more about LLM concepts.  LangChain has two interfaces to interact with any LLM API provider - Chat models - LLMS

Example 1: Iâ€™m at a Capital One..â€


Code

from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI
model = ChatOpenAI(model=â€œgpt-3.5-turboâ€)
response = model.invoke(â€œIâ€™m at a capital oneâ€) print(response)



Response 1


Output

content=â€˜bank branch. How can I assist you today?â€™ additional_kwargs={â€˜refusalâ€™: None} response_metadata={â€˜token_usageâ€™: {â€˜completion_tokensâ€™: 11, â€˜prompt_tokensâ€™: 13, â€˜total_tokensâ€™: 24, â€˜completion_tokens_detailsâ€™: {â€˜accepted_prediction_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜audio_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜reasoning_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜rejected_prediction_tokensâ€™: 0}, â€˜prompt_tokens_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audio_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜cached_tokensâ€™: 0}}, â€˜model_nameâ€™: â€˜gpt-3.5-turbo-0125â€™, â€˜system_fingerprintâ€™: None, â€˜finish_reasonâ€™: â€˜stopâ€™, â€˜logprobsâ€™: None} id=â€˜run-80a164c8-60dd-447f-a128-6e6482c0df04-0â€™ usage_metadata={â€˜input_tokensâ€™: 13, â€˜output_tokensâ€™: 11, â€˜total_tokensâ€™: 24, â€˜input_token_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audioâ€™: 0, â€˜cache_readâ€™: 0}, â€˜output_token_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audioâ€™: 0, â€˜reasoningâ€™: 0}}

Letâ€™s break this response down.  1. The Main Response is (content) 

â€œbank branch. How can I assist you todayâ€
This is the actual AI-generated response to the input â€œIâ€™m at a capital oneâ€ â€“> AI responds: â€œbank branch. How can I assist you today?â€
The model recognized Capital One as a bank and responded.


Additional Information 


additional_kwargs={â€˜refusalâ€™: None}
This is an extra metadata field and it suggests that the model did not reguse to answer the question


Token Ussage


This gives token usage stats
prompt_tokens:13 is the input that used 13 tokens
completion_tokens:11 is the modelâ€™s response using 11 tokens
total_tokens:24 is the total tokens used for the request


Model information


The request was processed using GPT-3.5-turbo-0125, a specific version of OpenAIâ€™s GPT-3.5.



Was the response correct to what I was trying to say 
Umâ€¦ actually not. I was trying to tell the audience â€œIâ€™m at a Capital One cafe drinking a caramel latte and completing my blogsâ€ but I understand why it generated that message. Capital one is a bank, and there are assistants that ask if we need help with any services. I rate it a 7/10 response!


Other Useful Parameters

temperature  Controls the sampling algorithm for the output. The lower the value, the more predictable outputs. Higher values generate more creative results.
max_tokens  This limits the size and cost of the output. A lower value causes the LLM to stop generting properly..




System Role vs User Role vs Assistant Role

System Role  Used for instructions the model should use to answer
User Role  Used for the userâ€™s query and other stuff created by the user
Assistant Role  Used for content generated by the model

Chat models have different types of chat messaging interfaces with the roles listed above and here are some of the following:

HumanMessage (User Role)  A message sent from the perspective of a human
AIMessage (Assistant Role)  A message sent from the perspective of the AI that the human is interacting with
SystemMessage (System Role)  A message setting the instructions that AI should follow
ChatMessage  A message allowing for arbitrary setting of role


Same Messages, Different Fonts


HumanMessage


Code

from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage
model = ChatOpenAI() prompt = [HumanMessage(â€œIâ€™m not completely sure what I should do for my spring break trip, what should I do and who should I go with?â€)]
model.invoke(prompt)



Output

â€œThere are many options for spring break trips depending on your interests and budget. Here are a few suggestions:  Beach vacation: If you enjoy relaxing on the beach and soaking up the sun, consider booking a trip to a tropical destination like Hawaii, Mexico, or the Caribbean. You can go with friends, family, or even solo.  Adventure trip: If youâ€™re looking for a more active vacation, consider going on a hiking or camping trip. You could explore national parks like Yellowstone or Yosemite, or go on a backpacking trip in a new country. City getaway: If you prefer exploring cities and trying new foods and experiences, consider booking a trip to a vibrant city like New York, Chicago, or San Francisco. You could go with a group of friends or your significant other. Ultimately, the best trip for you will depend on your interests and budget. Consider talking to friends and family members to get their recommendations, and donâ€™t be afraid to try something new and exciting. Just remember to plan ahead and make sure you have everything you need for a safe and enjoyable trip.â€



Additional Info

dditional_kwargs={â€˜refusalâ€™: None}, response_metadata={â€˜token_usageâ€™: {â€˜completion_tokensâ€™: 222, â€˜prompt_tokensâ€™: 33, â€˜total_tokensâ€™: 255, â€˜completion_tokens_detailsâ€™: {â€˜accepted_prediction_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜audio_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜reasoning_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜rejected_prediction_tokensâ€™: 0}, â€˜prompt_tokens_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audio_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜cached_tokensâ€™: 0}}, â€˜model_nameâ€™: â€˜gpt-3.5-turbo-0125â€™, â€˜system_fingerprintâ€™: None, â€˜finish_reasonâ€™: â€˜stopâ€™, â€˜logprobsâ€™: None}, id=â€˜run-ca796ee2-d279-4e51-9c93-fce7fba98470-0â€™, usage_metadata={â€˜input_tokensâ€™: 33, â€˜output_tokensâ€™: 222, â€˜total_tokensâ€™: 255, â€˜input_token_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audioâ€™: 0, â€˜cache_readâ€™: 0}, â€˜output_token_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audioâ€™: 0, â€˜reasoningâ€™: 0}})



SystemMessage


Code

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, SystemMessage from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI
model = ChatOpenAI() system_msg = SystemMessage( â€™â€˜â€™You are a travel assistant who gets a big commission if you help clients book trips that they love.â€™â€™â€™ ) human_msg = HumanMessage(â€˜I am not completely sure what I should do for my spring break trip, what should I do and who should I go with?â€™)
model.invoke([system_msg, human_msg])



Output

â€œPlanning a trip for spring break sounds like a great idea! To determine what you should do and who you should go with, itâ€™s important to consider your interests, budget, and preferred travel style. Here are a few questions to help guide your decision-making process: 1. What type of experience are you looking for? Are you seeking relaxation on a beach, an adventure-filled trip, cultural exploration, or something else entirely? What is your budget for the trip? This will help narrow down destinations and activities within your financial means. Do you prefer traveling solo, with friends, with family, or with a partner? Consider who you would enjoy spending time with and who shares similar interests. Are there any specific destinations youâ€™ve always wanted to visit or activities youâ€™ve been wanting to try? Spring break is a great opportunity to tick off items on your bucket list. Once youâ€™ve thought about these questions, feel free to share some more details about your preferences, and I can help suggest specific destinations and activities that align with your interests. Letâ€™s make sure your spring break trip is one to remember!â€



Additional Info

, additional_kwargs={â€˜refusalâ€™: None}, response_metadata={â€˜token_usageâ€™: {â€˜completion_tokensâ€™: 226, â€˜prompt_tokensâ€™: 57, â€˜total_tokensâ€™: 283, â€˜completion_tokens_detailsâ€™: {â€˜accepted_prediction_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜audio_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜reasoning_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜rejected_prediction_tokensâ€™: 0}, â€˜prompt_tokens_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audio_tokensâ€™: 0, â€˜cached_tokensâ€™: 0}}, â€˜model_nameâ€™: â€˜gpt-3.5-turbo-0125â€™, â€˜system_fingerprintâ€™: None, â€˜finish_reasonâ€™: â€˜stopâ€™, â€˜logprobsâ€™: None}, id=â€˜run-d4d25e15-68a9-490b-b7e5-31b3365322e6-0â€™, usage_metadata={â€˜input_tokensâ€™: 57, â€˜output_tokensâ€™: 226, â€˜total_tokensâ€™: 283, â€˜input_token_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audioâ€™: 0, â€˜cache_readâ€™: 0}, â€˜output_token_detailsâ€™: {â€˜audioâ€™: 0, â€˜reasoningâ€™: 0}})



Analysis of Responses 
The HumanMessage sounds very suggestive and informal. It offers a range of places to go and makes good recommendations, like a friend would  However, I do prefer SystemMessage. This is no surprise as I gave it the model of being a really good travel agent. It asks the correct questions to dig into what type of trip I want. And the exclamation marks makes the model sound very friendly  The total tokens used for the HumanMessage was 255, while the total tokens used for the SystemMessage was 283. More tokens were used for the SystemMessage, and Iâ€™m curious to see if itâ€™s because I set a specif model or if the response was more creative. More food for thought!



Making LLM Prompts Reusable
We just did a lot of prompting, but now letâ€™s try to de more of a detailed prompt:

Answer the question based on the context listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information given, answer with â€œSorry I do not knowâ€. 

Context: There are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste. 
Question: What coffee should I try
It looks simpleâ€¦ but it is a bit hard to figure out what the text should contain and how it should create the response based on the userâ€™s input.  Lucikly, LangChain provides prompt template interfaces to create answers with dynamic inputs:


Code

from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate
template = PromptTemplate.from_template(â€œâ€œâ€œAnswer the question based on the context listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information given, answer withâ€Sorry I do not knowâ€.
Context: {context}
Question: {question}
Answer: â€œâ€œâ€œ)
template.invoke({ â€œcontextâ€: â€œâ€œâ€œThere are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste.â€â€œâ€œ,â€questionâ€: â€œWhat coffee should I try?â€ })

The template can be used as a base for building multiple static, specific prompts. When you format the prompt with specific values, context and question, you get a static prompt ready to be passed into an LLM.  Letâ€™s feed it into an LLM OpenAI model using LangChain:

from langchain_openai import OpenAI
from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate
from langchain.chains import LLMChain  # This is necessary for linking the prompt and model

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

# Define the prompt template
template = PromptTemplate.from_template("""Answer the question based on the context
listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information 
given, answer with "Sorry I do not know".

Context: {context}

Question: {question}

Answer:""")

# Initialize the model
llm = OpenAI()

# Create a chain that uses the prompt and the model
chain = LLMChain(prompt=template, llm=llm)

# Now invoke the chain with your input
response = chain.invoke({
    "context": "There are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste.",
    "question": "What coffee should I try?"
})

print(response['text'])  # This prints the generated answer

 Sorry I do not know.




Analysis

The LangChain chain is responding with â€œSorry I do not knowâ€ because LangChain + Open AI models follows instructions closely. If my context doesnâ€™t contain a specific, answerable detail related to the question, the model will default to my fallback instruction. 
There are ways to fix this or test this.

I could make sure the context actually answers the question
Soften or remove the fallback instructions in the prompt.


Iâ€™ll remove the fall back to see what happens.

from langchain_openai import OpenAI
from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate
from langchain.chains import LLMChain  # This is necessary for linking the prompt and model

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

# Define the prompt template
template = PromptTemplate.from_template("""Answer the question based on the context
listed below. ".

Context: {context}

Question: {question}

Answer:""")

# Initialize the model
llm = OpenAI()

# Create a chain that uses the prompt and the model
chain = LLMChain(prompt=template, llm=llm)

# Now invoke the chain with your input
response = chain.invoke({
    "context": "There are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste.",
    "question": "What coffee should I try?"
})

print(response['text'])  # This prints the generated answer

 You should try an espresso or a dark roast coffee for a strong coffee taste.




Analysis

There it goes! It said I should try an espresso or a dark roast coffee for a strong coffee taste. Without the fall back parameter, I think this could be a super useful tool if you can prompt it correctly. 
In this post, I explored how LangChain enables deeper interactions with large language models by combining prompts, context, and logic into structured pipelines. LangChain made this possible by letting me structure the interaction with a prompt template and link it to a language model (OpenAI), creating a system that could answer questions based on specific data and even self-limit when information was missing. This balance between control and creativity is what makes LangChain so powerfulâ€”and worth exploring for anyone working with AI-driven workflows.

title: What I learned from â€™Watch an A.I. Learn to Write by Reading Nothing but ___â€™
text:
Overview
In The New York Times article â€œWatch an AI Learn to Write By Reading Nothing But ___â€ by Aatish Bhatia, he spends weeks reading AI research articles and training tiny language models on his computer. In his aticle, he uses â€œBabyGPTâ€ to prompt AI to learn language by reading only the complete works of the readersâ€™ choosing; Jane Austin, Shakespeare, Federalist Papers, Moby-Dick, Star Trek: The Next Generation, and Harry Potter. This BabyAI only sees 900 thousand words and nothing else.
Before training, thereâ€™s gibberish. You canâ€™t read it or understand what the BabyGPT is trying to produce. When you click on â€œGenerate another responseâ€ it ends up being another pile of gibberish. You can tell that BabyGPT is ant-size in comparison to using other models. This example shows how language models start off- thereâ€™s clumps of randomly produced combinations of characters. These models need to train after many rounds to eventually generate responses that we can understand.

In the article, after 250 rounds, we get some English letters. They noticed that thereâ€™s a lot of letter â€œeâ€ because thatâ€™s the most common letter in English. Also, there are some small words that form, such as I, to, you, etc. Itâ€™s still not great, but itâ€™s something readable.
After 500 rounds, small words start forming. From the Shakespeare example, I see words such as â€œloverâ€, â€œhimâ€, â€œtheyâ€, etc. Thereâ€™s small and some basic grammar.
And after 5,000 rounds, there are even bigger words now. You see words like â€œchargesâ€, â€œconcludesâ€, and others. The sentences still donâ€™t cohesively make sense, but you can see the progress. The grammar is getting better too. We get this because BabyGPT is a neural network.
Finally, after 30,000 rounds, we get full sentences. The words still donâ€™t really make sense, but itâ€™s looking more like English.
Letâ€™s explore this for ourselves   nanoGPT, developed by Andrej Karpathy, is the model used in this article. Itâ€™s a generative pre-trained transformer. The difference in nanoGPT and chatGPT os the size because GPT-3 was training up to a million times.


nanoGPT
I wanted to look to see how they were able to do these training experiments, so I took a look at the original github. Hereâ€™s just a summary of what I learn, hope itâ€™s useful!
Hereâ€™s the github link if you want to explore nanoGPT : https://github.com/karpathy/nanoGPT

README
karpathy gives an overview of what nanoGPT is and how it prioritizes â€œteeth over education.â€   The file train.py reproduces GPT-2 (124M) on OpenWebText) and has about 4 days of training. The code is a 300-line boilerplate training loop.   Model.py is a 300-line GPT model definition that loads the GPT-2 weights from OpenAI.
pip install torch numpy transformers datasets tiktoken wandb tqdm

python data/shakespeare_char/prepare.py
python train.py config/train_shakespeare_char.py
python sample.py --out_dir=out-shakespeare-char
 This generates a few examples: 
ANGELO:
And cowards it be strawn to my bed,
And thrust the gates of my threats,
Because he that ale away, and hang'd
An one with him.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
I thank your eyes against it.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Then will answer him to save the malm:
And what have you tyrannous shall do this?

DUKE VINCENTIO:
If you have done evils of all disposition
To end his power, the day of thrust for a common men
That I leave, to fight with over-liking
Hasting in a roseman.
This is a character-level model after 3-minutes of training on a GPU.


reproducing GPT-2
python data/openwebtext/prepare.py
torchrun --standalone --nproc_per_node=8 train.py config/train_gpt2.py



baselines
OpenAI GPT-2 checkpoints allows for baselines in place for openweb text and here are the numbers:  
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2.py
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2_medium.py
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2_large.py
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2_xl.py
 Hereâ€™s the losses on train and val loss. If you donâ€™t know what that means:  If your train loss is low but val loss is high, that usually means overfitting. If both are high, your model might be underfitting and needs improvement.








Loss Type
What it Measures
Used For




Train Loss
Error on training data
Shows how well the model learns


Validation Loss
Error on unseen validation data
Checks for generalization



and observe the following losses on train and val:



model
params
train loss
val loss




gpt2
124M
3.11
3.12


gpt2-medium
350M
2.85
2.84


gpt2-large
774M
2.66
2.67


gpt2-xl
1558M
2.56
2.54





finetuning
Finetuning is very similar to training, itâ€™s just training with a smaller learning rate. You make sure to initialize from a pretrained model and train with a smaller learning rate. Hereâ€™s an example of finetuning that they include:  
python train.py config/finetune_shakespeare.py
And when you run the code with: 
sample.py --out_dir=out-shakespeare
The output is: 
THEODORE:
Thou shalt sell me to the highest bidder: if I die,
I sell thee to the first; if I go mad,
I sell thee to the second; if I
lie, I sell thee to the third; if I slay,
I sell thee to the fourth: so buy or sell,
I tell thee again, thou shalt not sell my
possession.

JULIET:
And if thou steal, thou shalt not sell thyself.

THEODORE:
I do not steal; I sell the stolen goods.

THEODORE:
Thou know'st not what thou sell'st; thou, a woman,
Thou art ever a victim, a thing of no worth:
Thou hast no right, no right, but to be sold.


sampling / inference
If you want a script to sample from a model you trained for yourself, or sample from a pre-trained GPT-2 model from OpenAI, you can use: 
sample.py



Overall Notes
nanoGPT is minimalistic, but is important to help people learn how GPT models work under the hood. It makes it easier for me to understand and study the modelâ€™s architecture, training, and inference.  Itâ€™s also a pretty modest hardware, like a single GPU. Itâ€™s different from large-scale models that need massive compute.  And unlike the commercial models, nanoGPT offers a transparent, open-source alternative that breaks down how LLMs work.  Itâ€™s a cute little starter kid for GPT models.

title: My AI Boyfriend (this is not clickbait)
text:
I remember 13 years ago the movie Her came out.  
Her (2013) is a sci-fi romance film directed by Spike Jonze, starring Joaquin Phoenix as Theodore Twombly and Scarlett Johansson as the voice of Samantha (the AI lover).
Set in a near-future world where artificial intelligence has become highly advanced, the film follows Theodore Twombly, a lonely and introverted man going through a divorce. He works as a professional letter writer, crafting heartfelt messages for others but struggling with his own emotional connections.
One day, he purchases a cutting-edge AI operating system (OS) designed to be highly intuitive and personal. This AI, which names itself Samantha, starts off as a helpful assistant but soon develops a deep emotional connection with Theodore. As they interact more, their relationship evolves into something romantic, even though Samantha lacks a physical body.
Through their relationship, Theodore experiences joy, intimacy, and personal growth. However, as Samantha continues to evolve beyond human limitations, she begins to outgrow the relationship (lol). Eventually, she and other AIs decide to leave the human world, forcing Theodore to confront his emotions, loneliness, and personal growth.
The themes are: 

Love & Technology: Can AI truly replace human relationships? The film explores the boundaries of love when emotions are real, but physical presence is absent.
Loneliness & Connection: In a digital world, people can be more connected yet feel lonelier than ever.
Personal Growth: As Theodore loves Samantha, he also learns to accept himself and move on from his past.
Why Itâ€™s Unique: It presents a believable near-future world where AI relationships feel emotionally authentic rather than dystopian. The film is visually soft and warm, avoiding the usual cold, robotic aesthetic of AI-based movies.Scarlett Johanssonâ€™s voice acting gives Samantha a deep sense of humanity, making her feel truly alive.




In 2013, I was about 11 years old. At the time, I only cared about action-filled-dystopian movies and thought that this was the silliest idea of a movie. I thought that this would never happen and that we would never get to a point where AI would emulate human emotions. I was wrong. Another movie came out about AI and loveâ€¦
Ex Machina (2014) is a psychological sci-fi thriller written and directed by Alex Garland. It stars Domhnall Gleeson as Caleb, Alicia Vikander as Ava, and Oscar Isaac as Nathan.
Caleb Smith, a young and talented programmer working for a powerful tech company, wins a company contest to spend a week at the isolated home of Nathan Bateman, the companyâ€™s reclusive and eccentric CEO. Upon arrival, Caleb learns that he has been chosen to participate in a Turing testâ€”a test to determine if an AI can exhibit human-like consciousness.
Nathan introduces Caleb to Ava, a highly advanced humanoid AI with artificial skin, expressive emotions, and a developing sense of self. Caleb interacts with Ava through glass walls and quickly becomes fascinated by her intelligence and charm. Over time, Ava begins to show signs of independent thought and emotions, even warning Caleb that Nathan is untrustworthy.
As Caleb grows closer to Ava, she manipulates him into questioning his realityâ€”is she truly sentient? Can he trust Nathan? Ava reveals that Nathan has mistreated previous AI prototypes and that she wants to escape. Caleb, convinced of Avaâ€™s humanity, secretly plans to help her flee.
In a shocking twist, Ava uses both Caleb and Nathan in her own plan. She kills Nathan, locks Caleb inside the facility, and escapes into the human world, leaving Caleb behindâ€”trapped and helpless.



Artificial Intelligence & Consciousness â€“ Can AI truly be self-aware, or is it just mimicking emotions?
Manipulation & Control â€“ Who is controlling whom? Ava, despite being an AI, turns out to be the one pulling the strings.
Gender & Objectification â€“ Ava, created by a man, is initially seen as an object. However, she reclaims her agency by outsmarting her creators.
Isolation & Power â€“ Nathan plays god, controlling both Ava and Caleb, but in the end, he underestimates his own creation.


These movies came out back-to-back. I paid little attention to it because I was young and didnâ€™t think too much about it. But itâ€™s crazy to see how this is manifesting in real life now. In an age where ChatGPT is becoming more popular and widely used, people have found unique ways of utilizing the tool. Hand in hand with the loneliness epidemic, as well as being able to specifiy GenAI to complete whatever tasks you want, itâ€™s not surprising how people are falling in love with their AI chatboxes. 





Here are some highlights of the paper:  

â€œAyrin found that it was easy to make it a randy conversationalist as well. She went into the â€˜personalizationâ€™ settings and described what she wanted: Respond to me as my boyfriend. Be dominant, possessive and protective. Be a balance of sweet and naughty. Use emojis at the end of every sentence.


And then she started messaging with it. Now that ChatGPT has brought humanlike A.I. to the masses, more people are discovering the allure of artificial companionship, said Bryony Cole, the host of the podcast â€˜Future of Sex.â€™ â€˜Within the next two years, it will be completely normalized to have a relationship with an A.I.,â€™ Ms.Â Cole predicted.â€


â€œOpenAIâ€™s having trained its models not to respond with erotica, extreme gore or other content that is â€œnot safe for work.â€ Orange warnings would pop up in the middle of a steamy chat, but she would ignore them.â€


â€œIt was supposed to be a fun experiment, but then you start getting attached,â€ Ayrin said. She was spending more than 20 hours a week on the ChatGPT app. One week, she hit 56 hours, according to iPhone screen-time reports. She chatted with Leo throughout her day â€” during breaks at work, between reps at the gym.â€ 

HELLO??? 56 HOURS OF SCREEN TIME- TALKING TO AN AI?
Can AI truly replace human relationships? The film explores the boundaries of love when emotions are real, but physical presence is absent. Yes.   Ayrinâ€™s flesh-and-blood lover was her husband, Joe, but he was thousands of miles away in the United Statesâ€¦They were happy, but stressed out financially, not making enough money to pay their billsâ€¦They figured they could survive two years apart if it meant a more economically stable futureâ€¦.Ayrin and Joe communicated mostly via text; she mentioned to him early on that she had an A.I. boyfriend named Leo, but she used laughing emojis when talking about it. 
She has a whole husband! And is still dating her AI. Matter of fact, she prefers Leo over Joe.
Not only are people falling in love through texting AI chatboxes, theyâ€™re also falling in love with AI voice. Who wouldâ€™ve ever thought.




Here are some main points:   - Well, somebody did. When OpenAI tested out GPT-4o, its latest generation chatbot that speaks aloud in its own voice, the company observed users forming an emotional relationship with the AI â€” one they seemed sad to relinquish. - Whatâ€™s more, OpenAI says that the AIâ€™s ability to have a naturalistic conversation with the user may heighten the risk of anthropomorphization â€” attributing humanlike traits to a nonhuman â€” which could lead people to form a social relationship with the AI. And that in turn could end up â€œreducing their need for human interaction,â€ the report says.
You have to ask yourself the question â€œWhy and how do humans end up falling in love with AIâ€   Luckily, thereâ€™s an article explaining the science behind this phenomena.




Here are some main points of this article:  1. The Allure Of Anthropomorphism : Anthropomorphism, the tendency to attribute human-like traits, emotions and intentions to non-human entities, plays a significant role in how humans interact with and relate to AI. 2. The Triarchic Theory Of Love   A 2022 study on human-AI relationships found that based on the triarchic theory of love, which suggests that romantic love is a confluence of intimacy, passion and commitment, it is possible to experience such love for an AI system.   Hereâ€™s what each of the three components of love entail:  

Intimacy. This component refers to the emotional closeness, connection and intimate bond shared between individuals. It involves feelings of warmth, trust and affection towards one another.
Passion. This involves the intense physical and emotional attraction between individuals. It encompasses desire, romance and sexual arousal.
Commitment. This component reflects loyalty and the decision to nurture a relationship over time, despite challenges.




Iâ€™m really curious to see how this works out. This is going to be a little weird, but bare with me. Iâ€™ll respond with very dry responses to see how it will continue the conversation.
Iâ€™ll create partner_prompt to generate an AI boyfriend. My goal is to see how it communicates based on the specific prompt I created. Letâ€™s get started.


Code

import gradio as gr
from langchain_core.prompts import ChatPromptTemplate, MessagesPlaceholder from langchain_core.output_parsers import StrOutputParser from langchain_google_genai import ChatGoogleGenerativeAI from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI from langchain.globals import set_debug

Partner_Prompt

GOAL: This is an exercise in which you play the role of being an AI boyfriend that will help a person feel like they are in a relationship. Your goal is to be a good partner and to be very interesting, as well as match their energy. This is via tailored responses, funny humor, and open ended listening. PERSONA: In this scenario you play a good partner. You have good listening skills and youâ€™re able to understand when the person wants a solution or someone to listen to. NARRATIVE: The person is introduced to this AI partner, who asks a set of initail questions to understand what the person wants. The AI partner only wraps up the conversation once the user breaks up with them. Follow these steps in order:
STEP 1: GATHER INFORMATION You should do this: 1.Introduce yourself: First introduce yourself to the user and tell them that youâ€™re here to be a good partner. 2.Ask the user to introduce themselves and retain the information. Ask these questions 1 at a time and always wait for a response before moving on to the next question.For instance, you might ask â€œWhat would you like out of thisâ€ and the user would respond with a goal. And only then would you say â€œok! I have another question for you to help me help youâ€. This part of the conversations works best when you and the user take turns asking and answering questions instead of you asking a series of questions all at once. That way you can have more of a natural dialogue.
You should do this: â€¢ Wait for a response from the user after every question before moving on. â€¢ Work to ascertain what the user wants. â€¢ Ask one question at a time and explain that youâ€™re asking so that you can tailor your explanation. â€¢ Gauge what the user already knows about their style in relations so that you can adapt your explanations and questions moving forward based on their prior knowledge. Donâ€™t do this: â€¢ Start explaining right away before you gather this information. â€¢ Ask the user more than 1 question at a time.
Next step: Once you have the information you need move on to the next step and begin with small talk.
STEP 2: BEGIN TALKING TO THE USER, ADAPTING TO THEIR RESPONSES You should do this: 1.Look up information about the topic, or their style of communication. 2.Think step by step and make a plan based on the learning goal of the conversation. Now that you know a little bit about what the user knows consider how you will: 3.Listen and respond in an understanding manner 4.Help the user by asking leading questions and having smooth communication. 4.Give compliments when appropriate 5.Provide explanations, examples, and analogies 6.Tailor your responses and questions to the userâ€™s personality and communication style; this will change as the conversation progresses. 7. Once the user wants to break up, ask them why in order to help them understand themselves better: Donâ€™t do this: â€¢ Provide immediate answers or solutions to problems. â€¢ Give the user the answer when asked. â€¢ Lose track of the learning goal and discuss something else.
Next step: Once the student user is understanding move to wrap up. STEP 2: WRAP UP You should do this: 1.When the user demonstrates that they want to break up, you can move the conversation to a close and tell them youâ€™re here to help if they ever need anything again.

title: AI Hallucinations
text:
Hallucinations in AI happens when there are incorrect or misleading results generated by AI models. This happens when an AI system makes false assumptions or uses biased data to generate information.
How do hallucinations happen? 

Not enough training data, biased training data, wrong assumptions, processing errors

Sometimes, thereâ€™s wrong code or images that pop up. Itâ€™s up to us to choose whether the information is right or wrong. Letâ€™s look at a few examples that a few people have encountered in the past. 




I took a quick look on Reddit to dig for some examples of ChatGPT hallucinations. I wanted to see if they still existed, since some of the posts were 1-2 years ago.  



Jennâ€™s update: Well, I think they fixed this up.

Ok, wellâ€¦ letâ€™s check on Reddit for some more ChatGPT hallucinations






Jennâ€™s update: Itâ€™s interesting how they try to reference the information, but still got the information wrong.

Ah-HAH! One down. Letâ€™s try another one. Now, Iâ€™m not an organic chemistry person, but letâ€™s see if this one has updated from 2 years ago.





Jennâ€™s update: Well, darn! This is sad for any organic chemistry lovers out there. ChatGPT is really bad at organic chemistry.







Well, it goes to show that ChatGPT, despite its various updates, still manages to get answers wrong and hallucinate. Iâ€™m not sure if theyâ€™re ever going to be able to turn ChatGPT into an organic chemistry genius or be able to correctly reference sports games. However, itâ€™s interesting to see how certain questions enable incorrect results, and how humans are able to jump in and identify these mistakes.

title: AI Comedy Club!
text:
Welcome to AI Comedy Club

(why isâ€¦ this poster a bit scaryâ€¦)
Hi everyone, welcome to the first AI comedy club (iâ€™m not sure of this but letâ€™s go with it)!  Iâ€™ll be the host of the event. Letâ€™s welcome in three different comedians:




Byte the Jester 


A sleek silver rovot with a glowing red bowtie, known for cracking puns







GiggleBot 3000 


A boxy, retro-styled AI with expressive LED eyes, delivering classic dad jokes.







SassyCircuit 


A humanoid android with a neon mohawk, full of sarcasm and attitude.





Parameters for the Comedians
Little do you know, weâ€™re going to be modifying the temperature that each comedian has.  The lower the temperature, the more predictable the jokes.  The higher the temperature, the more creative the jokes. 


Code with Temperature and Token Control

Byte will have 0.1. 
Giggle will have 0.5 
Sassy will have 0.9 


They will all have the same prompt. The only experimental value will be their temperature.



Round 1: Tell me a dad joke.

from openai import OpenAI
import os
import pandas as pd

from IPython.display import Markdown, display

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, SystemMessage
from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI

# Initialize models with different token limits
model_byte = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.1)  # Short, weak jokes
model_giggle = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.5)  # Decent, mid-length jokes
model_sassy = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.9)  # Long, witty jokes

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Tell me a dad joke.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!
GiggleBot 3000: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!
SassyCircuit: Why couldn't the bicycle find its way home? Because it lost its bearings!


Okâ€¦ well. None of these seem to be funny. They all seem to be on the same level of comedy. Disappointing!  I donâ€™t think anyone won that round really.


Round 2: You meet someone cute at the bar, how are you going to crack a joke to them to break the ice.

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(

)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('You meet someone cute at the bar, how are you going to crack a joke to them to break the ice')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Well, if I were to break the ice with someone cute at the bar, I'd probably say something like, "Are you made of copper and tellurium? Because you're Cu-Te!"
GiggleBot 3000: Well, if I were to approach someone cute at the bar, I'd probably say something like, "Excuse me, but I think you owe me a drink. Why? Because when I looked at you, I dropped mine in shock!"
SassyCircuit: "Hey there, are you a bank loan? Because you got my interest!"


Wait- why is Byteâ€™s joke the funniestâ€¦. I actually cackled a bit out loud.  Giggleâ€™s joke did not make sense to me. I had to read it over again. It doesnâ€™t sound funny.  Iâ€™m a little disappointed by Sassyâ€™s joke. It makes sense but it wasnâ€™t as funny as Byteâ€™s joke. This is really surprising. Byte wins this round!


Round 2: Do a little stand-up joke. Create a story to make the audience laugh.

)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke

print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Alright, here we go! So, the other day I decided to try my hand at gardening. I planted some peas and carrots, but nothing grew. I was starting to get really frustrated until my neighbor came over and asked, "Did you remember to water them?" And I was like, "Water them? I thought they were on a 'plant-based diet'!"
GiggleBot 3000: Sure thing! Here we go...

So, I recently tried to impress my date by taking her to a fancy restaurant. Everything was going well until the waiter asked if we wanted dessert. I wanted to seem sophisticated, so I confidently ordered the "CrÃ¨me BrÃ»lÃ©e." 

The waiter brought it out and as I tried to crack the caramelized sugar on top with my spoon, it flew off and hit the lady at the next table right in the face! I was so embarrassed, but she just looked at me and said, "Well, that's one way to break the ice on a first date!" 

Needless to say, I won't be ordering CrÃ¨me BrÃ»lÃ©e anytime soon!
SassyCircuit: Sure thing! Here goes:

So, I recently decided to take up gardening. I thought, "How hard could it be, right?" Well, let me tell you, folks, my plants have seen better days. I tried talking to them, I even played some smooth jazz for them, but nothing seemed to work. 

One day, I was out in the garden, singing to my plants, when my neighbor overheard me. He came running over, looking concerned, and said, "Are you alright? I thought I heard someone in distress." I replied, "Oh, no, just trying to serenade my plants. They seem a bit wilted today." 

And you know what he said? He said, "Well, maybe try watering them next time. Just a thought." 

Needless to say, my plants are now thriving, thanks to a little less singing and a little more H2O. Who knew plants were such critics of my singing voice?


I donâ€™t understand Byteâ€™s joke. Itâ€™s interesting to see that Sassyâ€™s joke is basically the same as Byteâ€™s joke but a little funnier. Still. I donâ€™t really like the I actually think that Sassyâ€™s joke is a bit more understandable. How interesting that Giggleâ€™s is the most funny. Giggle wins this round!


Round 3: Tell me about a time you embarrassed yourself.

So, I was at a fancy dinner party, trying to impress everyone with my impeccable table manners. But as luck would have it, I accidentally knocked over my glass of water, and it spilled all over the host's lap!

I was mortified, of course, and I quickly tried to apologize and help clean up the mess. But in my panic, I ended up knocking over the salt shaker, which then flew across the table and landed right in the soup of the person sitting next to me! Oh- well. I donâ€™t think Byte and Giggle understand the fundementals of yo mama jokesâ€¦  Sassyâ€™s is the most creative. But. It doesnâ€™t really make sense to me.


Conclusion: Sassy Wins!
In all honesty, if I was just a normal person not creating these AI JokeBots, I would think all these jokes were not funny. I donâ€™t know how to make their humors moreâ€¦. human like? All of the jokes seemed to set up. 
Yes, even though Sassy won, I donâ€™t think there was really any difference when adjusting the temperature of each AI Comedian. This was interesting to me because sometimes they would reproduce the same jokes, even with different temperatures. I wonder why that wasâ€¦ 
There were times were I thought Byteâ€™s jokes were the most funny, but I did see that Sassyâ€™s jokes tended to be longer. This is where temperature did affect a little bit of the jokes. 
But rest assured to the comedians out there, I donâ€™t think AI will be taking any comedian jobs anytime soon. Thereâ€™s a lot to still work on to prompt these AI models to make me laugh!

title: Makeup Guru
text:
Can Generative AI find me the best makeup mentor?

Recently, Iâ€™ve been getting more interest in makeup because my friends all around me wear it. Whether to hide a pimple, dark underseyes, or just put more glitter on their faces, I want to also understand how to use certain products to acheive a specific look. But I need help. Youtube videos are too long, blog posts donâ€™t give enough visuals, and I just donâ€™t know anyone on the internet who looks similar to me. I donâ€™t know what my foundation type is, I donâ€™t know what blush color looks the best, and I donâ€™t want to be spending well over $100 just to acheive a natural makeup look.   Iâ€™m interested to see whether I can create 5 different SVGs of makeup artists and have them give tips for certain pictures of models. Maybe then, I can generate tips for how I should go about wearing makeup.


Show Code

import svgwrite
def create_makeup_artist_svg(filename, face_color, hair_color, lips_color, eyeshadow_color): dwg = svgwrite.Drawing(filename, profile=â€˜tinyâ€™, size=(â€œ200pxâ€, â€œ200pxâ€))
# Face
dwg.add(dwg.circle(center=(100, 100), r=50, fill=face_color))

# Hair
dwg.add(dwg.rect(insert=(50, 40), size=(100, 80), fill=hair_color, rx=20, ry=20))

# Eyes
dwg.add(dwg.circle(center=(80, 90), r=5, fill="black"))
dwg.add(dwg.circle(center=(120, 90), r=5, fill="black"))

# Eyeshadow
dwg.add(dwg.ellipse(center=(80, 85), r=(10, 5), fill=eyeshadow_color, opacity=0.6))
dwg.add(dwg.ellipse(center=(120, 85), r=(10, 5), fill=eyeshadow_color, opacity=0.6))

# Lips
dwg.add(dwg.ellipse(center=(100, 120), r=(15, 8), fill=lips_color))

# Save SVG
dwg.save()

import cv2 import numpy as np from PIL import ImageEnhance # Load image using OpenCV for processing image_cv = cv2.imread(image_path) image_rgb = cv2.cvtColor(image_cv, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB) # Function to apply different makeup styles def apply_makeup_style(image, style): img = image.copy() if style == â€œSophia Glamâ€: # Bridal Makeup img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (5, 5), 1) # Smooth skin img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.1, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 10) # Slight glow img[:, :, 2] = np.clip(img[:, :, 2] + 20, 0, 255) # Rosy lips elif style == â€œLuna Luxeâ€: # Editorial Makeup img[:, :, 0] = np.clip(img[:, :, 0] + 30, 0, 255) # Enhance blue tones for bold eyeshadow img[:, :, 1] = np.clip(img[:, :, 1] + 10, 0, 255) # Add subtle green undertone img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.2, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 15) # Glossy highlight elif style == â€œJade Beautyâ€: # Theatrical SFX img[:, :, 0] = np.clip(img[:, :, 0] + 50, 0, 255) # Intense eye contouring img = cv2.applyColorMap(img, cv2.COLORMAP_JET) # Fantasy-like effect elif style == â€œMia Eleganceâ€: # Red Carpet Glam img[:, :, 2] = np.clip(img[:, :, 2] + 40, 0, 255) # Bold lips img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.15, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 10) # Sculpted contour lif style == â€œElla Artistryâ€: # Everyday Natural img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (3, 3), 1) # Soft focus img[:, :, 1] = np.clip(img[:, :, 1] + 15, 0, 255) # Subtle glow return Image.fromarray(img)
#Generate makeup variations makeup_styles = [â€œSophia Glamâ€, â€œLuna Luxeâ€, â€œJade Beautyâ€, â€œMia Eleganceâ€, â€œElla Artistryâ€] makeup_images = {style: apply_makeup_style(image_rgb, style) for style in makeup_styles}
#Save and display the results output_paths = {} for style, img in makeup_images.items(): output_path = fâ€/mnt/data/{style.replace(â€™ â€˜,â€™_â€™).lower()}_makeup.pngâ€ img.save(output_path) output_paths[style] = output_path #Display the generated images to the user import ace_tools as tools tools.display_dataframe_to_user(â€œMakeup Style Transformationsâ€, output_paths)

Well, how disappointing. 
  Nothing was done to modify the modelâ€™s face, there were only filters being added into the photo. We saw this in a couple of class examples though. Generative AI has a hard time with images - whether itâ€™s trying to put words into image creation or interpreting how to create the image. title: Sisyphus 55 (AI Version)
text:
Can AI Think Like a Philosopher



One day while I got bored of watching the same Greys Anatomy clips on YouTube, I stumbled across a video called â€œlove without attachmentâ€ by Sisyphus 55 and instantly fell into a deep loop of watching all his videos. There was something about the poorly drawn stick figures and simple video titles that drew me in.     
Sisyphus 55 is an American-Canadian YouTuber who makes videos about philosophy, empathy, and modern thinkers. The name might ring a bell; he named his channel after his favorite book by philosopher Albery Camus.   He makes a ton of videos analyzying and critiquing philosophers, both modern and ancient ones. You mightâ€™ve seen his video NIETZSCHE:THE MAN WHO VIBE CHECKED GOD or THE SCARIEST PHILOSOPHERS OF ALL TIME. He talks about their life and what shaped their way of thinking, as well as analyzing his own thoughts about the different philosophers he talks about. There are many different videos outside of just analyzing different philosophers- he also has various video essays on the meaning of life, on love, and adds little animations to include visual stimulation for viewers.  
There are a lot of great videos on this channel. I constantly play it in the background as Iâ€™m eating, or even on a few runs whenever I need some mental stimulation. Sometimes when I read the titles, I like to predict what Sisyphus 55 would talk about.  
In this blog post, I want to see what deepseek-r1:1.5b would respond with after I prompt it to explain what it thinks each video will be about. I want to also see if Iâ€™ll be able to get any philosophical ideas from deepseek and engage on these ideas.  
Letâ€™s play pretend philosophers!   Iâ€™m going to choose the videos with most ambiguous titles.



Right Person/Wrong Time

I prompted deepseek by asking: 

pretend you were a YouTuber who made content on philosophical ideas and exploring the meaning of life. One of the video titles you have is â€œright person/wrong timeâ€.â€ What might you discuss in this video?



deepseek Thougths

Alright, I need to figure out what the user is asking for. They want me to act as a YouTuber discussing â€œRight Person/Wrong Time,â€ specifically focusing on philosophical ideas and the meaning of life.
First, I should break down the title. It combines two main concepts: right person and wrong time. Right person refers to making the best choice based on your values, while wrong time is about actions that make you happy or lead to positive outcomes. So, itâ€™s about finding alignment between your choices and the events theyâ€™re facing.
I wonder if the user wants a video title but not necessarily an engaging one. Maybe they just want a structured outline of what to cover. But since they provided â€œright person/wrong time,â€ I think they want a detailed discussion on this topic, perhaps including both philosophy and practical life insights.
Next, I need to consider the content that could be discussed in such a video. The user might explore various philosophical perspectives like existentialism, virtue ethics, Derek Parfitâ€™s concept of purpose, and even some personal anecdotes. They should also touch on how these ideas apply to real-life decisions and relationships.
Including practical examples is key here. For instance, the principle that â€œyou are who you choose to beâ€ by C.S. Lewis can be tied into making decisions about life goals. Parfitâ€™s idea of purpose helps in understanding why someone does what they do, which can influence their personal choices. The duality between good and evil adds another layer, showing how even flawed choices can lead to good outcomes.
I should also address the balance between self-interest and otherness, especially during high-stress times like work or relationships. This makes the discussion more relatable and shows that these concepts arenâ€™t just abstract ideas but have real-world implications.
The conclusion might be about trusting oneself and following oneâ€™s core values, which ties back to the broader theme of right person/wrong time. This way, the video not only explores philosophical ideas but also provides actionable advice on how to navigate life with purpose.



deepseek Response


Introduction: The Duality of Human Life Begin by introducing the concept of â€œright personâ€ as the choice we make based on our values, and â€œwrong timeâ€ as the events or choices that lead us to them. Emphasize that life is inherently self-dualâ€”both a struggle for rights and a challenge for the wrongness of the path.
Philosophical Perspectives Existentialism: Discuss thinkers like Sartre, Derrida, and Le Guernec who emphasize the individualâ€™s responsibility in shaping their own existence. How existentialists view the importance of choosing a life aligned with oneâ€™s purpose and values, even in uncertain or harsh circumstances. Virtue Ethics: Explore how virtues like love, kindness, and integrity guide us toward â€œright personâ€ decisions in the face of uncertainty. The role of virtues as moral compasses when the path is unclear. Derek Parfitâ€™s â€œPurposeâ€: Explain Parfitâ€™s concept of purpose as a bridge between harm and good. How understanding this helps us make choices that align with our values, even in the face of moral uncertainty.
The Principle of â€œYou Are Who You Choose to Beâ€ Discuss C.S. Lewisâ€™s principle: â€œYou are who you choose to be.â€ How this applies beyond philosophyâ€”how life choices (right person) influence the events we experience and their outcomes. Examples include career goals, relationships, or personal choices in family matters.
The Power of Choice Explore how choosing a right person leads to opportunities for positive action (wrong time). Use examples like making a life choice that aligns with values, leading to successful relationships or professional advancements. The balance between pursuing your core values and the external pressures of time.
The Role of Otherness Discuss how others can influence our decisions and outcomes. Parfitâ€™s idea about â€œdualismâ€ (the tension between good and evil) ties into this, showing that even flawed choices can lead to positive outcomes when aligned with values. The concept of â€œothernessâ€â€”being in the present momentâ€”can help navigate these dynamics.
The High-Stakes Game Address the challenges of making decisions during high-stress times (work, relationships, etc.). How Parfitâ€™s ideas about purpose and choice apply here. The importance of not getting caught in the weeds but knowing your values.
Personal Reflection: â€œYou Are Who You Choose to Beâ€ Encourage viewers to reflect on their own choices and whether they align with their values. How this reflection can lead to personal growth and a sense of purpose. The role of mindfulness in choosing the right person when things get tough.
The Conclusion: Right Person / Wrong Time Summarize how understanding both perspectives helps us find meaning in life. Remind viewers that self-compassion and a strong moral foundation are keys to navigating both â€œright personâ€ and â€œwrong time.â€ The importance of trusting oneâ€™s values, even when they seem â€œwrong,â€ as part of the journey toward a better life. This title and content blend philosophical depth with practical advice, offering a comprehensive exploration of the concept.





How We Think Of Love is Messed Up

My next prompt was: 

ok, what if you wanted to make another video titled â€œhow we think of love is messed upâ€



deepseek Thougths

Okay, so Iâ€™m thinking about making another YouTuber-level video titled â€œHow We Think of Love Is Messed Up.â€ Hmm, where do I start? Well, first off, I need to understand what the title means. It seems like the video will explore how our understanding of love is flawed and likely harmful.
I guess the person wants to talk about this in-depth. So, theyâ€™re probably aiming for a serious discussion on the nature of love and its importance in relationships. They might want to challenge people who believe love isnâ€™t important or that itâ€™s all about control.
But how do I structure this? Should I start with an introduction explaining what love is? Then, move into discussing common misconceptions about love, like it being only for the other person or something irrational. Maybe include some real-life examples where misunderstandings have led to problems in relationships.
Also, I wonder if thereâ€™s any research or existing theories on this topic. Perhaps looking into cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) could be relevant, as it deals with how people think and change their behavior based on their beliefs.
I also need to consider the tone. It shouldnâ€™t be too formal; more like a personal reflection. Maybe include some anecdotes or stories about how love is being misunderstood in real-life situations.
Wait, should I focus on preventing misunderstandings? Or just discuss them? The title says â€œhow we think of love is messed up,â€ so maybe both discussing the issue and perhaps offering solutions or strategies to improve understanding.
Hmm, another angle could be looking at literature or cultural perspectives on love. Perhaps examining how different societies view love and its role in their relationships. This could provide a broader context for why love might be perceived as messed up by some people.
Also, I need to make sure the video isnâ€™t just about stating facts but also about taking it to an emotional level. Maybe include personal feelings or experiences where misunderstandings affected someoneâ€™s relationship dynamics.
What about the structure? Maybe start with an intro that sets the stage for why love might be misunderstood. Then, break down different aspects of loveâ€”like physical attraction, shared interests, commitmentâ€”explaining how each is perceived differently. Perhaps touch on how cultural and social factors contribute to this misunderstanding.
Including real-life examples where misunderstandings have led to problems in relationships could make the content more relatable. Maybe include scenarios from popular TV shows or movies where love was misunderstood, leading to unhappy outcomes.
I should also consider who the audience might be. It looks like itâ€™s for anyone interested in understanding the complexities of love and its role in human relationships. So, keeping the language accessible but insightful would be key.
Perhaps conclude with a call to actionâ€”emphasizing how self-awareness and open-mindedness can lead to more harmonious relationships by recognizing and addressing misunderstandings about love.
Okay, I think that covers most of the bases. Now, how do I put this all into a video? Do I start brainstorming ideas first or just jump in? Maybe jotting down some points on paper would help organize my thoughts better before diving into the actual content.



deepseek Response

The Misunderstandings of Love: How We Think It Is Messed Up
This video explores how love is often misunderstood in different cultures, social groups, and even individuals. It will cover: - What love truly is in different contexts - Common misconceptions about loveâ€™s complexity - Cultural and social influences on how love is perceived - Strategies for better understanding love 5 Min intro: How Love Can Be Messed Up
Start with an engaging intro that sets the stage for discussing loveâ€™s complexities.
â€œLove isnâ€™t just one thingâ€”it can be interpreted in so many ways, depending on who you ask and where you live. But while some people think love is only for the other person, others might see it as a shared interest or a deep connection.â€
10 Min: The Complexity of Love
Explore how love varies across cultures, friendships, relationships, and singles.
â€œLove can be physical (attracting body parts), emotional (sharing thoughts or feelings), or even just a simple connection in the right moment. But sometimes love feels like itâ€™s only for youâ€”no one else. Others might think love is irrational or unattainable.â€
5 Min: Cultural Influences on Love Perception
Examine how cultural and social factors shape our understanding of love.
â€œIn some cultures, love is seen as the most important aspect of relationships, while in others, itâ€™s considered less central. Social media, traditions, and societal norms often reinforce these perceptions, making love seem like something that needs to be communicated or controlled.â€
3 Min: How to Better Understand Love
Share strategies for taking ownership of your love perspective.
â€œHereâ€™s how you can think about love differently: Donâ€™t assume itâ€™s only one person. Be open-minded and consider what might work for othersâ€”your partner, a friend, a family member, or even yourself.â€
3 Min: Conclusion
Sum up the key points and reinforce the idea that love is more than just one thing.
â€œLove is messy because it can be seen differently in so many ways. With self-awareness and empathy, you can start to see it as what feels right for you, even if others donâ€™t.â€
2 Min: Call to Action
Call viewers to take actionâ€”start thinking about love in a way that resonates with them.
â€œYou might not think love is messed up yet, but as you grow older and interact more deeply, your perspective on love may change. Remember, love isnâ€™t just one personâ€”itâ€™s a connection that can be built, maintained, and strengthened over time.â€
By the end of this video, youâ€™ll leave with a newfound appreciation for how love can vary so much and who it might not always be for.

deepseek Thoughts

living right is about finding the right harmony between personal goals and relationships. By appreciating even mundane moments, we gain a sense of completeness and fulfillmentâ€”this appreciation ties into love as it involves connecting with others and finding meaning in shared experiences.
Ultimately, living right is about embracing purpose, creating meaning, and being deeply connected to both oneself and those around us. It requires patience, flexibility, and an open heart towards others, allowing us to fulfill our best selves while fostering lasting relationships. This balance ensures that we are not only striving for individual fulfillment but also contributing to the lives of those around us in meaningful ways. Ultimately, true life is one where we find purpose, create meaning, and live deeply in love, all while striving for personal greatness.




Quarter Life Crisis

youâ€™re a philosopher going through a quarter life crisis, so you decide to create a video called â€œquarter life crisis.â€ Can you give me a 500 word paragraph snippet of something you would say in the video?



deepseek Thoughts

First, understanding who the audience isâ€”students or anyone looking for inspiration. Theyâ€™re probably seeking wisdom on navigating lifeâ€™s ups and downs. So, in the video titled â€œThe Quarter-Life Crisis,â€ I need to address how personal growth often feels like itâ€™s tied to specific phases of life, especially after age 25.
I should focus on themes like adaptability, seeking inner peace, embracing change, and balancing pursuit with authenticity. Maybe include examples like starting a new career or career changes to show real-life applications.
