title: ChatGPT Helped Me Find My Village Language
text:
ChatGPT Helped Me Find My Village Language


I grew up in a polyglot household. The three bedroom house in North Philly consisted of my mom, dad, paternal aunt (å§‘å¦ˆ gÅ« mÄ), and paternal grandparents (é˜¿å«² a maa and é˜¿çˆº a ye). Oh, and my little brother but he was only babbling at the time while my grandparents were still alive. Everyone spoke at least 5 languages: Mom knew Mandarin, Cantonese, Vietnamese, Hakka, and English. Dad and his side spoke their village language, Mandarin, Cantonese, Vietnamese, English, Thai and Lao.   Soâ€¦it came to no surprise that I didnâ€™t know how to speak any language properly. Like. Seriously. I was put in ESL until second grade. My guma told me that I used to be able to sing in Vietnamese and the village language, while my mom told me that I used to mix up Cantonese and Mandarin all the time. The languages congealed, and I would always create odd sentence structures through a combination of everything I heard. No wonder why, even as an adult, I end up making my own words and creating sentences that only make sense to me.   I decided on English because it was the easiest and most used language. But by deciding on that, I lost a lot of retention in these other Asian languages. Especially after my grandparents died, my vocabulary reduced 10 fold.   â€œItâ€™s ok thoughâ€ I thought. Half the world speaks Mandarin. No one in my family really speaks Hakka. Cantonese is a little harder to learn, but all of Hong Kong speaks it and Southern China. Thai and Lao are well known. But I was stumped on the village language. Thereâ€™s no written record, only my dad and aunt speak it together now, and I DONâ€™T EVEN KNOW WHAT ITâ€™S CALLED TO SEARCH IT UP.   I could only BARELY understand itâ€¦ but my dads side all spoke it during their reunions. I was pissed. I kept asking every year if they could teach me, but all they said was â€œitâ€™s a dying language. Once we pass, youâ€™ll probably never hear it again.â€ HOW IS THIS SUPPOSED TO HELP ME.  

Fast forward to a month agoâ€¦
Guma, Dad, and I went to the Chinese supermarket and they were speaking the village language. The cashier asks in Mandarin, â€œWhat language are you guys speakingâ€ and my aunt replies â€œA variation of Thai.â€ A variation of Thai?? What do you mean that our village language is a variation of Thai?? For context, my dadâ€™s side lived in Äá»“ng ÄÄƒng, which is Northern Vietnam. How did a Thai language get all the way to Northern Vietnam, while sounding like a mix of Vietnamese and Cantonese?

  

I had enough. I needed to figure out what our village language was. But Iâ€™ve been Google Searching for years and nothing came up.   The only helpful information I knew was these little tid bits: 

Itâ€™s from Äá»“ng ÄÄƒng.
Itâ€™s a variation of Thai/Lao/Cantonese.
Some common phrases (phonetically spelled) are â€œDey zoo me?â€ which means â€œhow are youâ€, â€œKhin caoâ€ which means eat rice, â€œMi owâ€ which means donâ€™t need.

Last night, I decided why not use ChatGPT to help me find my village language. I didnâ€™t have hope because I had tried searching on Google for so long.



ChatGPT Linguist Time
Below captures the conversation I had with ChatGPT.
      

I was skeptical of the results, so I looked into the different audios. TÃ y sounded the closest to my village language.. but I still wasnâ€™t so sure.   Then next thing you know, Iâ€™m on Youtube searching up â€œTÃ y Languageâ€ and I stumble upon this video of a woman.  

And holy cow. I found it. I finally found my village language.



TÃ y or Thá»• Language Audio Breakdown
In the video, she introduces herself and talks for 1 minute about her language. I knew 90% of what she was saying, and she sounds exactly someone from my hometown community. This was monumental for me. I looked at the comments to see that other people are also excited to find one video documenting a woman speaking colloquially in TÃ y.   I looked at the English translation and saw that it was somewhat incorrect- it didnâ€™t really capture the informalness of our language.   Either way, I watched the video about 8 times. I was so happy to have finally put a pin on something Iâ€™ve been investigating since I was young. I dug deeper for the next hour, learning more about the language and also the history of the people who spoke it. Only 1.63 million people speak this language. And with more of the elders dying out, Iâ€™m assuming that number is even more small now.  



Telling My Cousin
After this remarkable deep dive, I texted my cousin at 1:33am in the morning about my discovery. Hereâ€™s our text message exchange:
 
Well well well. Turns out her and my other cousin had discovered our village language 2 weeks prior with the help of a linguist professor. As you read in the text exchange, it took him a week to find our village language, whereas AI found it with three simple chats. This is insane  


What Does This Mean for Linguistics and Languages in General
A quick Google search shows 

The world is losing languages at an alarming rate, with estimates suggesting that up to 90% of the worldâ€™s languages could disappear within the next century. This equates to, on average, one language disappearing every two weeks. Many of these languages are small, indigenous languages, often lacking a standard written form High Risk: Approximately 40% of the worldâ€™s estimated 7,000 languages are already endangered, according to UNESCO. 

TÃ y is spoken by ~1.63 million people. Imagine other languages that are spoken with less than a million people. Although ChatGPT wasnâ€™t able to correctly teach me phrases or words in TÃ y (I searched and tried), it was able to correctly identify the language. What does this mean for the linguist world?   Will AI be able to help find more dying languages, retain these languages, or help teach people these languages. I hope for people like me who have been struggling to discover their parentsâ€™ natives tongues, that theyâ€™ll be able to utilize AI to help them rediscover lost languages.  


Personal Note
I didnâ€™t plan on using this as a blog post idea. This just so happened to come from curiousity at 1:00am in the morning. Iâ€™m so glad it happened because it helped me get a few steps closer to communicating with my dadâ€™s side of the family. This has been by far my most favorite blog post, and itâ€™s slowly becoming a passion project for my cousins and I to record down our village language. To anyone out their whoâ€™s interested, ask you parents if thereâ€™s a dying village language they knowâ€¦ hopefully AI can help you discover something new.

title: Valentines Day Poems
text:
Current AI systems cannot have emotions in the sense that humans doâ€¦ but are they able to detect and analyze human emotion? 
While they can be programmed to recognized and respond to human emotions, they can simulate emotional responses without truly feeling them 
I want to see if AI is able to read love poems and analyze them to the extent that human beings analyze them. Letâ€™s get started! 




Jenn: There is a love poem called â€œOn Fighting Transienceâ€, what does this title mean to you?


ChatGPT:  The title â€œOn Fighting Transienceâ€ suggests a struggle against impermanenceâ€”perhaps an attempt to hold onto something fleeting, like love, beauty, or life itself. It evokes a deeply romantic and philosophical idea: the desire to resist the inevitable passage of time and the loss that comes with it. In the context of a love poem, it could explore themes like:  Eternal love despite the impermanence of life.  Cherishing moments before they slip away.  Memory and longingâ€”trying to preserve a love that has passed.  Defying fateâ€”resisting change, distance, or even death in the name of love.  It feels like a perfect theme for Valentineâ€™s Dayâ€”an ode to the enduring nature of love, even in the face of timeâ€™s relentless march.


Jenn: Here is the poem, please tell me what it means and how you analyze it 


On Fighting Transience  My favorite authors create from memory,  write odes and odysseys sparked by recollection,  scrape the walls of their skulls prodding poetry to life.  You do the same, subtly  showering me with stories of family til tears line your face,  soft sobbing like slow plucks of violin strings,  turning tension to beauty and I want to cherish  this moment for a little while longer.  Pailing out the sinking boat of history that floods my head,  waves and fogs from trying to retain everything Iâ€™ve ever done,  replacing older memories with something new, less worthless,  recreating poetry and prosody in this roomâ€™s low light,  Iâ€™ll start here â€”  holding your hand as we push chess pieces across the board,  overworking gray matter while you disregard strategy,  and I watch you smile at each loss.  Nixing squares of black and white,  mixing pain and pleasure as we succumb to headaches and heart pains,  soon subsumed by pasts that flow off tongues like river water,  puddle in the air before invisible boundaries,  collide against secret dreams till weâ€™re both still.  Your head pressed against mine, sincerely silent  because words wonâ€™t do this moment justice.  Sitting on the floor, learning to share the air for several seconds,  pretending our familial pain is impermanent, promising  things will be better tomorrow, or maybe the day after,  or maybe next week, and soon I forget  because truly I lost track of time  the moment you entered my arms, that first handshake,  then hug, making us both fools, fate-bound,  spinning round and round in revolutions I wonâ€™t recover from,  so I embrace this chess-laden dance, drink in the sweetness of your humor,  recalling the moment we first met,  me, tongue-tied and stupid,  and you, asking if I wanted to take a picture,  asking if I wanted that moment to last. 





Analysis of On Fighting Transience
This poem is a deeply emotional meditation on memory, love, and the struggle against impermanence. It explores the ways in which we try to hold onto moments, people, and feelings, despite timeâ€™s inevitable passing.
Theme 1: Memory as a Tool for Fighting Time
The poem begins with a reflection on how authors and poets create from memory, turning recollections into lasting art. The speaker admires this ability, yet seems to struggle with their own attempts to do the same. Thereâ€™s an urgency in the lines:

Pailing out the sinking boat of history that floods my head,
waves and fogs from trying to retain everything Iâ€™ve ever done,

This suggests a fear of forgetting, a frantic attempt to preserve experiences before they slip away.
Theme 2: Love and the Desire to Hold Onto Moments
The heart of the poem is a love story intertwined with nostalgia. The speaker describes intimate moments with their partnerâ€”playing chess, sharing laughter, feeling the weight of past pain. Thereâ€™s a sense of trying to freeze time, particularly in lines like:

I want to cherish this moment for a little while longer.
Pretending our familial pain is impermanent, promising things will be better tomorrowâ€¦

This highlights the contrast between what we wish to be permanent (love, connection, laughter) and what inevitably fades (memories, pain, even people).
Theme 3: Love as an Anchor in Timeâ€™s Revolutions
The closing lines bring the poem full circle. The speaker reminisces about their first meeting, recalling how their partner asked:

if I wanted to take a picture,
asking if I wanted that moment to last.

This suggests that from the very beginning, there was an awareness of timeâ€™s fleeting natureâ€”that love and connection are temporary, but we still seek to make them last, even if only in memory.
Symbolism and Imagery - Chess: A symbol of strategy, time, and careful planning. The partner disregards strategy, suggesting they live in the moment, whereas the speaker overthinks. - Water (waves, fog, river water): Symbolizes memory and timeâ€™s fluidityâ€”it flows, puddles, disappears, and cannot be fully contained. - Hand-holding and physical closeness: Represent a desire for permanence, for grounding oneself in the present moment despite the inevitable passing of time.
Final Thoughts
This poem beautifully captures the human struggle against transienceâ€”the attempt to preserve fleeting moments through memory, love, and poetry itself. It suggests that while we canâ€™t truly stop time, we can hold onto the essence of moments through connection, storytelling, and remembrance.
Would you like to incorporate these themes into your blog post? This poem ties in perfectly with Valentineâ€™s Day because it speaks to loveâ€™s impermanence and the desire to make moments last.
